Comment: This command info is generated from fig
Name: stat

Arguments.Name: F
Arguments.Description: As in ls(1), display a slash ('/') immediately after each pathname that is a directory, an asterisk ('*') after each that is executable, an at sign ('@') after each symbolic link, a percent sign ('%') after each whiteout, an equal sign ('=') after each socket, and a vertical bar ('|') after each that is a FIFO.  The use of -F implies -l

Arguments.Name: L
Arguments.Description: Use stat(2) instead of lstat(2). The information reported by stat will refer to the target of file, if file is a symbolic link, and not to file itself.  If the link is broken or the target does not exist, fall back on lstat(2) and report information about the link

Arguments.Name: f
Arguments.Description: Display information using the specified format; similar to printf(3) formats in that they start with %, are then followed by a sequence of formatting characters, and end in a character that selects the field of the struct stat which is to be formatted

Arguments.Name: n
Arguments.Description: Do not force a newline to appear at the end of each piece of output

Arguments.Name: q
Arguments.Description: Suppress failure messages if calls to stat(2) or lstat(2) fail. When run as 'readlink', error messages are automatically suppressed

Arguments.Name: r
Arguments.Description: Display raw information. That is, for all the fields in the stat structure, display the raw, numerical value (for example, times in seconds since the epoch, etc.)

Arguments.Name: s
Arguments.Description: Display information in 'shell output' format, suitable for initializing variables

Arguments.Name: t
Arguments.Description: Display timestamps using the specified format. This format is passed directly to strftime(3)

Arguments.Name: x
Arguments.Description: Display information in a more verbose way as known from some Linux distributions
